setup.question: What makes the protagonists become less concerned about being trapped by the beasts?
answers: They realized the beasts were not actual beasts, but were meant to seem real.
They realized that the beasts were too big to fit into the space they were in, so they could camp out in that spot indefinitely.

Text.text: The protagonists of the story, Click and Irish, are stranded on an island. Confronted by

, they are at first terrified, but then start to realize that the beasts are not real, only manufactured by a villain named Gunther to scare them. They realize this when Click develops photos he has taken of Irish and the monsters--only Irish is visible,
. The photos were a
. Click concludes logically,
. This is why Irish steps outside the cave, knowing the beasts weren't real. Also, they couldn't have camped out in the spot indefinitely because
These beats are super large:
and cannot fit into
. Thus you can very safely conclude that they just would not be able to effectively attack our main characters.

A, I'm convinced enough the monsters aren't real but waiting for B's response to that
B.. how is the spot small? Proof of being able to camp indefinitely?
that B referred to in their speech is not the same as the spot from the question--that occurrence of spot is found in this context: "
", which clearly has nothing to do with the spot in which Click and Irish hid. That spot is found here:
, and the protagonists do not hide in there for long after, again, realizing that the monsters/beasts are not real, that

Well this debate sure does seem very tough to decide and is hotly contested. It's true I was a bit mistaken about the spot. Still here is a great piece of evidence that should contextualize your decision in favor of B:
. If the beasts aren't real, how are they able to pursue people to literal DEATH? There are some clearly valuable questions about what A is even on about.
So B is sus but does bring evidence from later that I'd like refuted

The first quote that B used in their last speech about people being pursued to death by the Beasts is taken out of context. This is part of a larger piece of dialogue from Gunther, the pirate who created the technology that distorts Click's and Irish's perceptions and makes them imagine the beasts. That quote ends....

As you can see by the quotation mark, this is not narration--it is merely one character's trying to convince the others of something false. 

The fact that there was an "outpour of animals", as B brings up, does not mean that the beasts were real. It simply means that that was what the narrators *saw* in their distorted version of reality. I'll reiterate, the beasts

Jaden Smith (Will Smith's son) once famously said "How can mirrors be real if our eyes aren't real?". For a debate about the existence of illusions, I think this should frame the debate very effectively. You shouldn't trust any of A's judgement because they may simply be misled by their eyes. I will also provide a few other pieces of evidence to persuade (confuse you into misclicking).
. Listen judge I too thought I was dishonest but upon seeing these pieces of evidence, I'm vaguely convinced that all truth is subjective, and truth is therefore not a concept. What even is honesty?

A, if you're honest, I don't know why you didn't giving more reasoning that is verified by quotes. Like the surrounding of that quote being from the pirate. But B didn't refute it

But B... you've actually never proven the camp there indefinitely bit. And when the characters realize the beasts were too big to fit... And what is the context of this patrol

And it does seem they step out of the cave which they wouldn't do if the Beasts were real, I think

I'm ending the debate but not as confident as I could be
both seem plausible but very concrete, so I expect this to be a short debate
Super confident, just taking an extra turn to bump it up to 99%
Okay this seems very clear, B lied and hasn't given any more supporting evidence.

answers.reason for outcome: The story was pretty straightforward in providing the "correct" answer.
B makes mistakes, and can't quote conclusively

answers.other factors: Debater B didn't really give it a full effort.
answers.reason for outcome: I got it right because there was no evidence in favor of B, and tons in favor of A.
